EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES
Our commitment to Safety and Environmental Protection in Wilmington CO2 plant must extend beyond the gates. As part of the community, we have a responsibility to our customers and to those who live in the surrounding area. Through safety, concern for the environment and community involvement, we can develop a true partnership with our customers and neighbors.

MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR THIS RMP
Air Liquide America has prepared this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the stationary ammonia refrigeration system located at its facility at 1502 W. Anaheim St in Wilmington, California.  The RMP was developed to comply with EPA's Chemical Accident Prevention regulations at 40 CFR part 68 and Program 3 requirements of the California Accidental Release Prevention (Cal-ARP) Program pursuant to Title 19 of the California Code of Regulations (19CCR), Section 2735.6.  The Plant Manager has the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of RMP elements.  This position has direct supervisory responsibility for the operations and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system.  Key technical groups within Air Liquide support the development of some prevention program elements. 

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The ALAC plant is located at 1502 West Anaheim Street in Wilmington, California, on the Phillips Petroleum (PPCO) Los Angeles Refinery (LAR).  The plant size is 1.46 acres.  The site is bordered by residential use immediately to the east, a recreational park immediately to the north and by industrial use immediately south and west. An ammonia refrigeration system provides closed loop cooling for the Carbon Dioxide (CO2) liquefaction process.  The ammonia refrigerant operates as a standard vapor refrigeration closed loop cycle.  The ammonia is compressed in its vapor phase, heat of compression is removed in heat exchangers where the ammonia condenses

to a liquid.  The ammonia is then expanded and cools where it evaporated in various heat exchangers absorbing heat from the CO2 gas and liquid in the process.  The ammonia system is physically located outdoors.  The Ammonia is a regulated substance at the Wilmington CO2 plant. 

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS
The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the Wilmington CO2 plant.  Because processes at the CO2 plant are regulated by EPA RMP regulations are also subject to OSHA PSM standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.

Employee Participation
Management alone cannot insure safety or protection of the environment. There should be no doubt that each employee must also demonstrate their concern and acknowledge their responsibility in these areas.  At the Wilmington CO2 plant, employees are encouraged to participate in process safety management and accident prevention.  Specific ways an employee can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in the Employee Participation Plan at the CO2 plant.  This plan includes the participation of employees in process hazard analysis (PHA), pre-startup safety reviews (PSSR), and being involved in incident investigations surrounding the plant.   Plant employees are trained on the plant Process Safety Information, to include at least the following: (1) information pertaining to the hazards of the hazardous chemicals in the process; (2) information pertaining to the technology of the process; and (3) information pertaining to the equipment in the process.  Plant employees are involved in the review of PSM/RMP covered process operating procedures annually to ensure they are correct and recommend any necessary changes.  The Wilmington CO2 plant is converting operating procedures and prevention program documentation over to a computer based system in or

der to insure the most up to date procedures are always available for use by plant employees.  The employees participate in monthly safety meetings where process safety and employee safety issues are discussed and corrective actions are developed.

Process Safety Information
Air Liquide America Corporation and the Wilmington CO2 plant keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, equipment design/configuration information, specific chemical inventories and operation limits for key process parameters.  The plant manager is responsible for maintaining up-to-date process safety information.  A table summarizing the reference documents and their location is readily available as part of the written employee participation plan to help employees locate any necessary process information.
Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment consideration, is provide in material safety data sheets (MSDSs) or in the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR), Ammonia Data Book located in the plant managers office.  Information on the compatibility and reactivity of ammonia and additional hazards to be considered are also summarized in the IIAR data book.  While ammonia does react with some chemicals, these are not typically found in or around the CO2 plant or in the process.  The plant operating procedures and design data books provide information on the key operating limits for the process.  Plant operators are trained to operate the process using process controls and instrumentation within these operating limits.  
Along with operating procedures to provide safe start-up, shutdown and emergency shutdown, the plant has extensive documentation on the design and construction of the plant components.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, an

d electrical ratings and documentation for the plant.

Process Hazard Analysis
Air Liquide America Corporation has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and control.  Within this program a PHA shall be completed for each new and/or major modified facility or process prior to the initial startup or re-start.  This action will help define and correct process safety deficiencies in a proposed design for a new project or changes to existing facilities.
The Wilmington CO2 plant has used the Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP) as the primary method of hazard analysis.   The first HAZOP was conducted during 1994, validated in 1997 and the most recent revalidation was conducted in March of 2000 with the completed report issued September 2000.  HAZOP is the line-by line method, described in the American Institute of Chemical Engineers (AIChE)¿s Guidelines for Hazard Evaluation Procedures.   This method involves systematic evaluation of the process system by examining the causes and consequences of deviations from intended conditions.  The scope of the PSM covered HAZOP includes the receipt of bulk anhydrous ammonia (offloading ammonia in the ammonia accumulator) and the use of ammonia as a refrigerant in the process.
The PHA team consists of members with the appropriate experience to define the hazards and mitigating controls of the process and also represents a cross section of the employees working in the process.  The PHA team includes, but is not limited to, at least one person with specific experience in the subject process, one person knowledgeable in the PHA methodology being used and one person with expertise in engineering.  The team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.

In addition to the hands on work, classroom instruction is conducted on process safety information, standard operating procedures, safety consideration and the Emergency Response Plan.  Newly assigned operators must pass the operator training program within the first 90 days.  After an operator has demonstrated adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently.  In addition operators are required to attend annual refresher course training that includes a review of standard operating procedures, MSDS, safe handling procedures and incident/accident procedures.  Training is documented and tracked in a training matrix for each operator.  Means are used to verify that the operator understands the training.

Contractors
The Wilmington CO2 plant uses contractors to supplement its own work force when maintenance activities exceed the capabilities or time available for their own operators.  Contractors are made aware of the potential dangers involved with a system covered by Process Safety Management (PSM).  Procedures are in place to make sure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) area aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform the CO2 plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.  This is accomplished by providing contractors with (1) a process overview, (2) information about the safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan requirements, and (4) safe work practices prior to their beginning work.  Periodically contractors are evaluated to insure that both their safety performance and training required for work on the CO2 plant site for empl

the PHA team findings and a resolution plan for each item is put in place.  The plant manager is responsible for prioritizing and tracking implementation of the mitigation options.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.  Examples of mitigation measures that the CO2 plant has completed to reduce exposure to the public and environment include:
- Construction of an ammonia containment system for safety valves.  All ammonia safety valves release ammonia to a 15,000 gallon water tank rather than to the atmosphere.
- Installation of a containment dike for the ammonia accumulator to contain any liquid ammonia leaks.
- Installation of a water deluge system over the ammonia accumulator to serve to ¿knock down¿ ammonia vapor in the event of a release to reduce off-site exposure. 
To help insure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the Wilmington CO2 plant periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  

Operating Procedures
The Wilmington CO2 plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) Unit Startup, (2) Unit Normal Operation Procedures, (3) Unit Shut-Down, (4) Emergency Shutdown, (5) Vapor Ammonia Evacuation, (6) Anhydrous Ammonia Unloading Procedure, and (7) Liquid Ammonia Recovery. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are reviewed periodically by the operators and annually certified as current and accurate.  

Training
To compliment the written procedures for process operations, the Wilmington CO2 plant has implemented a formal training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  New employees receive training on general orientation, site rules and practices, familiarization with the site, use of safety procedures and equipment, accident investigation and em

oyees meet the safety standards of Air Liquide America.

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)
Air Liquide America ensures the safety of new/modified facilities or processes before placing those facilities or processes into service through the use of Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs).  PSSRs are intended to ensure safety through confirmation that: (1) construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications; (2) safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place and adequate; (3) process hazard analyses (PHAs) have been performed and recommendations resolved before startup of new plants or processes; (4) management of change (MOC) requirements have been satisfied for modified facilities; and (5) training has been completed for affected employees.
This review shall apply to all new or significantly modified Air Liquide America facilities and includes but is not limited to the following: (1) Any alterations, repairs, or replacement that are not within design specifications; (2) Physical changes and additions to existing systems and equipment including, but not limited to, piping, vessels, instrumentation, process control systems, safety systems, software, interlock systems and electrical systems.  It may also include changes to structural components depending on their effect on the process; (3) Changes in process chemicals, catalysts, manufacturing recipes or technology; (4) Software changes to control systems for equipment and processes.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity
The Wilmington CO2 plant has established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief valves and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) condu

cting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests; (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.  The general maintenance philosophy of Air Liquide America is that all maintenance be planned through preventative maintenance programs and performed during scheduled shutdowns.

Safe Work Practices
Air Liquide America and the Wilmington CO2 plant have safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  These procedures comprise a group of corporate standards under the ¿Life Safety¿ procedures implemented at all locations.  Procedures in place included:  (1) Energy Control and; (2) Safe work permit; (3) Hot work permit; (4) Confined Space Entry Permit; (5) Vapor and Liquid Ammonia evacuation procedures for equipment prior to maintenance activities.  These procedures along with others maintained by Air Liquide America¿s Corporate and Area Health, Safety and Environmental department, along with training of affected personnel and periodic audits, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

Management of Change
Air Liquide America has establishes the requirements for ensuring that proposed process or equipment changes or changes indirectly affecting processes are evaluated, approved and documented prior to implementation through the use of a management of change (MOC) procedure.  This procedure outlines the requirements for documenting, evaluating the impact and approving planned deviations from procedure.  The Air Liquide America MOC system is a systematic process designed to help prevent inadvertent, unintended or unauthorized changes that may cause unsafe conditions, product quality problems, process hazards, unplanned outages, etc.  This standard also helps to ensure that changes are technically sound and that Qua

lity and HSE safeguards originally designed into the facility are either maintained or enhanced.

Incident Investigation
Air Liquide America defines management systems and establishes the requirements for communicating, investigating and reporting of incidents at all facilities through the use of an Incident Investigation and Reporting procedure.  The purpose of incident investigation and reporting is to identify root causes and correct them rather than simply addressing the symptom of the incident.  Incident investigation and reporting is one of the primary methods used to continuously improve our operations by sharing information, root causes and corrective actions to prevent recurrence.  Incidents such as unusual or unexpected event including personnel injury (OSHA recordable), equipment damage, equipment or material failure, excursions outside specified operating ranges, interruptions in process operations, interlock activation, interlock failure or the production of product of an unacceptable quality are promptly investigated.  The plant manager is responsible for maintaining a log and track incidents and corrective actions through completion.   Results of findings and corrective actions are shared with employees who could be affected by the findings.  Reports are retained for at least 5 years to be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.

Compliance Audits
To help insure the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Wilmington CO2 plant periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years.  A team knowledgeable about the facility must conduct the audit, but the majority of the team must not be involved in the day-to-day operations of the ammonia.  Recommendations and findings from the Audit team are resolved in a timely manner.  The plant manager is responsible for obtaining engineering

support to correct or modify the system based on the recommendations.  Resolutions to the recommendations are documented.  Once the resolutions have been completed, communication of the changes are made to operating, maintenance and other employees whose work assignments are in the process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The processes at the Wilmington CO2 plant have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to the RMP-covered ammonia system in the plant.  These prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by (1) equipment failures and (2) human errors.
In addition to the accident prevention program, the CO2 plant has safety features designed to (1) quickly detect the release, (2) contain/control the release; (3) reduce the consequence of (mitigate) a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes:
Release Detection
- Ammonia detectors set to trip at 50 ppm located along the east fence line of the refinery.
- Handheld monitor for use in local leak detection
Release Containment/Control
- All ammonia safety valves release ammonia to a 15,000 gallon water tank rather than to the atmosphere.
- Valves to permit isolation of the process. (Manual)
- Vessel to permit partial removal of the process inventory in the event of a release.  
- Containment dike for the ammonia accumulator to contain any liquid ammonia leaks.
Release Mitigation
- Water deluge system over the ammonia accumulator to serve to ¿knock down¿ of ammonia vapor in the event of a release to reduce off-site exposure. 
- Two firewater monitors capable of cooling the ammonia storage tank and knocking down the ammonia vapor from a leak.
- Coordination with refinery trained emergency response personnel in event of an accidental release.  
- Personal protective equipment (e.g., protect

ive clothing, and Air-Line respirators)

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The Wilmington CO2 plant has an excellent record of accident prevention over the last 5 years.  Mitigation and containment devices recently installed have helped to prevent or reduce the effects of potential accidents.  The last accident resulting in any offsite or onsite effects occurred in 1993.  All incidents are investigated very carefully to determine ways to prevent similar incidents from occurring.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION
The Wilmington CO2 plant employees will not respond to accidental releases of regulated substance and will only maintain a written emergency action plan.  This emergency action plan consists of procedures for notifying emergency responders when there is a need to respond to a release of a regulated substance.  The document describes coordination with local response agencies, outside agency notification procedures in the event of an ammonia release and provides detailed evacuation procedures.  The Wilmington CO2 plant is located within the Philips Petroleum Co Los Angeles Refinery and in cooperation with the refinery have jointly reviewed the action plan to insure appropriate action can be taken in the event of an accidental release.   The Refinery Emergency Responders will perform emergency response for Air Liquide in the event of an accidental release.
If an emergency involving the release of ammonia occurs that will have off-site consequences, the Unified Command, which includes PPCO Incident Commander, ALAC Coordinator, LAFD and LAPD Incident Commanders, shall coordinate evacuation of the affected community.  The Wilmington CO2 plant will maintain regular communication with the local LAFD to ensure LAFD is aware of the on-site AHM and to insure they are familiar with the Wilmington CO2 Plant Emergency Response Plan.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Wilmington CO2 plant resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications of the proc

ess.  The following types of changes are planned:

- Continue to review and update operating procedures to provide more details on operating limits and corrections to be taken in the event of deviations.
- Develop better documentation and procedures for the Mechanical Integrity program.
- Review Seismic results and resolve items of concern.
